o: Creating a low-fidelity visual guide that represents the skeletal framework of a website/app
Rough sketch focusing on layout/structure, using placeholders (boxes/lines) without detail
Detailed representation closer to final design, including some visuals/content but not fully polished
Static high-fidelity design showing the final look (colors, typography, images) without interactivity

q: Difference: Wireframe vs Mockup vs Prototype?
o: Wireframe = Structure; Mockup = Visuals; Prototype = Interactivity/Behavior
To define information hierarchy and layout capability before investing in visual design
Sketch-style low-fidelity wireframing tool that mimics whiteboard drawing
Placeholder text used to demonstrate where copy will go without distracting with meaningful content
Notes explaining functionality, behavior, or content requirements attached to UI elements
Designing/Testing with limited knowledge of internal workings (between Black and White box)
To prevent stakeholders from focusing on color choices instead of layout/structure
The bottom edge of the screen visible without scrolling (Critical for key content placement)
The user's visible area of a web page

q: What is 'Grid System' role in wireframing?
o: Provides structure and consistency for aligning elements (Columns, Gutters)
Vertical sections where content is placed
Space outside the grid (between content and screen edge)
Creating wireframes for multiple breakpoints (Mobile, Tablet, Desktop) to plan adaptation
Starting layout design with the smallest screen constraints
Organizing and structuring content so users can find what they need (Sitemaps, Heirarchy)
Diagram showing the hierarchy and linking of pages in a site
Diagram showing the path a user takes through the system to achieve a goal
Button or link prompting the user to take a specific action (e.g. 'Sign Up')
Large, prominent area at the top of a homepage (usually image + headline + CTA)
Bottom section of a page containing copyright, links, contact info
Vertical column usually containing navigation or secondary content
Navigation trail showing current location in hierarchy (Home > Electronics > TV)
Window that appears on top of main content and disables background interaction
Layer that sits on top of the UI (e.g. Menu, Tooltip)
Small version of an image/video used for previews
Component allowing users to cycle through a set of content (images/cards)
Vertically stacked headers that expand to reveal content
Three-line icon used to toggle a hidden menu (usually on mobile)
Interface control to switch between two states (On/Off)
Menu that expands downwards to show a list of options
Area where user can enter text data
Text identifying what data belongs in an input field
Hint text inside an input field that disappears when typing starts
Small pop-up providing description/help when hovering over an element
Container grouping related information (Image, Title, Text, Link) into a single unit
Circular button floating above UI promoting the primary action (Material Design)
Wireframe-like placeholder shown while content is loading
Header that remains fixed at the top of the viewport while scrolling
Loading more content automatically as user scrolls down
Dividing content into discrete pages (1, 2, 3... Next)

q: What is 'Breadth vs Depth' in navigation?
o: Breadth = number of items at one level; Depth = number of levels in hierarchy
Visual clues indicating how an element can be used (e.g. Button shape implied clickability)
Mark that signals the affordance (e.g. underline signals a link)
Psychological rules describing how humans perceive visual patterns/groups
Items close together are perceived as related
Items that look alike (shape/color) are perceived as a group
Arranging elements to imply importance (Size, Boldness, Position)
Empty area around elements used to reduce clutter and guide eye
User eye path on text-heavy pages (Top horizontal, Middle horizontal, Left vertical)
User eye path on visual-heavy pages (Top left -> Top right -> Bottom left -> Bottom right)
Rapid freehand drawing to explore ideas quickly
Pre-made UI shapes (Buttons, Icons, Inputs) dragged onto canvas
Pre-structured layout/file to start a design from
A reusable element where changes update all instances
A copy of a Master component
Describing logic/rules that static images can't show (e.g. 'Button is disabled until input filled')
Simple interactive wireframe where clicking links leads to other screens
Scale from Sketch -> Low-Fi Wireframe -> High-Fi Wireframe -> Mockup -> Prototype
Early stages, brainstorming, validating structure (Cheap to fail)
Late stages, validating visuals, detailed user testing, developer handoff
Reveals layout issues (long names, breaking text) that Lorem Ipsum hides
Images defined by mathematical paths (Scalable infinitely without pixelation)
Images defined by a grid of pixels (Loses quality when scaled up)

q: Standard screen width for Desktop wireframe (generic)?
Standard screen width for Mobile wireframe (generic)?

o: Popular grid system divisible by 2, 3, 4, 6 (highly flexible)
Pixel widths where the layout shifts/adapts (Mobile -> Tablet -> Desktop)
Building for modern browsers but ensuring generic functionality for older ones
Starting with basic HTML and layering CSS/JS for better browsers
Arrangement of visual elements on a page
Sketching interfaces on paper and manually simulating interaction
Iterative process of quickly building and testing interfaces
Small bits of text (labels, errors, hints) guiding user
Personality/Emotions conveyed through copy (e.g. Friendly, Professional)
Anyone with an interest/vested buy-in in the project (Client, Boss, Team)
Cyclical process of refining design based on feedback
Placing elements along a common line (Left, Right, Center)
Difference between elements (e.g. Light vs Dark) to create distinction
Reusing visual elements to create unity and familiarity
Distribution of visual weight (Symmetrical vs Asymmetrical)
Uneven distribution but still feeling balanced via weight/position
Composition guideline dividing image into 9 grids; points of interest on intersections
Mathematical ratio (1:1.618) typically found aesthetically pleasing
The user's internal understanding of how a system should work based on past experience
Time to acquire a target is a function of the distance to and size of the target (Big/Close is faster)
Time it takes to make a decision increases with the number and complexity of choices
Average person can only keep 7 (plus or minus 2) items in their working memory
Users spend most of their time on other sites, so they prefer your site to work the same way as others
Belief that users don't scroll (False: users do scroll, but top content must hook them)
Keep It Simple, Stupid (Simplicity guarantees greatest levels of user acceptance/interaction)
Observing real users attempting to complete tasks on the wireframe/prototype
Comparing two versions of a design to see which performs better (Split testing)
Visual representation of data showing where users click, scroll, or move mouse (Hot/Cold areas)
Measuring where a user looks (fixations) and how their eyes move (saccades)
Designing products so they can be used by people with disabilities (Blind, Deaf, Motor, Cognitive)
Software that reads text/content on screen aloud for visually impaired users (e.g. NVDA, VoiceOver)
Text description of an image used by screen readers and if image fails to load
Measure of the difference in perceived luminance between text and background (e.g. 4.5:1 for WCAG AA)
Sequence in which interactive elements receive focus when pressing the Tab key
Visual indicator (outline) showing which element allows input/interaction via keyboard
Visual change when mouse pointer is over an element
Visual appearance while an element is being clicked/tapped
Element is visible but cannot be interacted with (often grayed out)
Visual feedback (Red border/text) indicating valid input is missing or incorrect
Visual confirmation (Green checkmark) that an action completed successfully
Design for when there is no data to display (e.g. Empty cart, No messages)
Process of introducing a new user to the product's features and value
Step-by-step guide showing how to use specific features
Temporary overlay pointing out specific UI elements to explain them
Visual indicator of how much of a task is completed
Control to increase/decrease a value (often with + and - buttons)
Control allowing selection of a value from a range by dragging a handle
Calendar interface for selecting a date
Accordion stacks vertically; Tabs arrange horizontally (usually)
Large expandable menu showing many options/sub-categories at once (Amazon)
Footer that stays at the bottom of the viewport or content (whichever is lower) or fixed
Background moves slower than foreground while scrolling, creating 3D depth effect
Minimalist style using simple 2D elements without shadows/textures/gradients
Design language using grid-based layouts, responsive animations, and depth (shadows/paper metaphor)
Design style mimicking real-world objects/textures (e.g. Leather calendar, detailed trash can)
Design trend using soft shadows to make elements appear extruded from the background
Design trend using background blur and transparency to mimic frosted glass
Collection of reusable components, standards, and documentation for building consistent UIs
Document defining the visual standards (Colors, Fonts, Logos) for a brand
Collection of user interface design patterns (e.g. Forms, Navigation, Cards)
Complex / conditional logic and dynamic content in prototypes without coding
Container with multiple states used to create sliders, carousels, and sticky headers
Widget that displays a dataset (list/grid) where editing one item updates all
Feature allowing different layouts for specific screen widths (Breakpoints)
Invisible area on a static image made clickable in a prototype
Visual effect when changing between screens/states (Fade, Slide, Push)
Speed curve of an animation (Ease-in, Ease-out) making it feel natural
Small, functional animation providing feedback (e.g. Like button heart pop)
Visualization of the process a person goes through to accomplish a goal (including emotions)
Fictional character created to represent a user type that might use a product
Tool to articulate what a user Says, Thinks, Does, and Feels
Research method where users organize topics into categories (helps build IA)
Evaluating the findability of topics in a site structure (IA) without visual clutter
Longitudinal research where users record their daily activities/thoughts regarding a product
Observing and interviewing users in their natural environment while they work
Quick, low-cost usability testing in public places (coffee shops) with random people
Recording of the parts of the screen a user clicks on while using a site
Percentage of users who take a desired action (Buy, Sign up)
Percentage of visitors who navigate away from the site after viewing only one page
Percentage of customers who stop using/paying for a service over a period
Metric measuring customer loyalty ('How likely are you to recommend us?')
Key Performance Indicator (Measurable value demonstrating effectiveness)
Upper half of the front page where important news is placed (Visible without unfolding)
Vertical space between lines of text (Line height)
Adjustment of space between two specific characters
Uniform adjustment of spacing over a range of characters
A single word left alone at the bottom of a paragraph/column
A single word/short line left alone at the top of a new column/page
Using nonsense text/symbols to represent text in a layout to focus on form
Very small, rapid rough sketch to explore layout ideas
Rough sketch of a layout (advertising agency term)
Collage of images/materials/text to define the visual style/feeling of a project
Set of pre-made UI components (buttons, inputs) to speed up design
Web-based vector graphics editor and prototyping tool allowing real-time collaboration
Vector graphics editor for macOS focused on UI design
Vector-based user experience design tool for web and mobile apps
Collaboration tool for handing off designs to developers (Specs, Assets)
Version control system for design files (Sketch/XD)
Specific situation in which a product or service could potentially be used
Problem/situation that occurs only at an extreme operating parameter (Rare but important)
Default scenario where everything goes as expected without errors
Diagram of the sequence of movements/actions of people or things involved in a process
Flowchart grouping processes into lanes (Who does what?)
Bar chart illustrating a project schedule
Visual method for managing work (To Do, In Progress, Done columns)
Agile framework for managing knowledge work (Sprints, Stand-ups)
Set period of time (e.g. 2 weeks) during which specific work has to be completed and made ready for review
List of tasks required for the project (features, bugs, tech debt)
Meeting held at the end of a sprint to discuss what went well and what could be improved
Short daily meeting (15 mins) to synchronize activities and plan next 24 hours
Understanding the user's needs, barriers, attitudes, and aspirations
Analyzing observations to define the core problem you have identified
Generating a wide range of ideas/solutions (Brainstorming)
Building inexpensive, scaled-down versions of product features to investigate solutions
Rigorous testing of complete product using best solutions identified from prototyping
Design process model: Discover (Diverge), Define (Converge), Develop (Diverge), Deliver (Converge)
Narrowing down choices to the best solution (Making choices)
Focus on obtaining feedback as early as possible so that it can be used to make quick decisions (MVP)
Integrating UX design into the Agile software development methodology
Linear, sequential approach where each phase must be completed before the next begins
Visual and textual cues that suggest a path to the desired information
Total amount of mental effort being used in the working memory
Simplify interface, remove distractions, use familiar patterns, chunk information
Deteriorating quality of decisions made by an individual after a long session of decision making
User interface crafted to trick users into doing things they didn't mean to (e.g. subscribing)
Easy to get into (Subscribe), but hard to get out of (Unsubscribe)
Guilting the user into opting into something ('No, I don't like saving money')
Designing products that respect user rights, privacy, and well-being
Methodology that enables and draws on the full range of human diversity (accessibility + usability for all)
Design of products/environments to be usable by all people without adaptation (Architecture origin)
Ongoing expansion or addition of new features in a product (Scope creep)
Implied cost of additional rework caused by choosing an easy solution now instead of a better approach
Accumulation of design inconsistencies and quick fixes that need to be cleaned up later
Layout using percentages for widths so it stretches/shrinks with the viewport
Layout using fixed pixel widths that does not change with viewport size
Uses several distinct fixed layouts for specific screen sizes (snapping)
App to preview designs on mobile device in real-time
Platform to share/download files, plugins, and widgets created by other users
Online whiteboard for brainstorming, diagramming, and collaboration (by Figma)
Property that allows frames to grow/shrink based on contents (Flexbox logic)
Rules defining how objects behave when their parent frame is resized (Left, Right, Scale)
Group of components allowing property toggling (e.g. Button: Primary/Secondary, Hover/Default)
Defining interactions (hover, click) within the component set itself to work automatically in prototypes
Animation feature that looks for matching layers between frames and interpolates changes
Third-party script producing a feature not native to the tool (e.g. Unsplash for images)
Interactive object on the canvas (e.g. Poll, Timer, Kanban board)
Saved color, text, or effect settings that can be applied across the project
Breaking the link between an instance and its main component (becomes a regular frame)
The original definition of a component; defines properties for all instances
Changes made to an instance (Text, Image) that differ from Main Component but keep link
Reverting an instance back to the exact state of the Main Component
Combining shapes to create complex vector paths
Showing only parts of a layer that fall within the shape of another layer
Converting multiple layers/shapes into a single vector path
Converting a line (stroke) into a filled shape (path)
Aligning vector points exactly to the pixel grid for sharpness
Defining format (PNG, SVG, JPG) and scale (1x, 2x) for output
Automatically adjusting spacing between multiple selected objects to be equal
Moving an object by a small increment (Arrow keys)
Moving an object by a larger increment (Shift + Arrow keys, usually 10px)
Guide overlay showing measurements along top and left of canvas
Lines pulled from rulers to align objects manually
Visual grid of pixels visible at high zoom levels
Log of changes allowing you to restore previous states of the file
Tool allowing collaborators to pin notes/feedback on specific parts of design
View for developers to see CSS, spacings, font details, and assets without ability to edit design
Popular plugin for managing advanced Design Tokens in Figma
Accessibility suite plugin (Contrast checker, Vision simulator)
Plugin to insert high-quality stock photos directly into shapes
Plugin providing access to thousands of vector icons (Material, FontAwesome, etc)
Plugin to populate designs with realistic text strings, images, and icons (Microsoft)
Plugin to easily draw flow arrows between frames
Manual annotation of specs (dimensions, margins, colors) for developers (mostly obsolete with Inspect)
Process of transferring design assets/specs to developers for implementation
Review process where designer checks the implemented build against the design specs
Pejorative or descriptive term for the detailed work of adjusting layout implementation
Using your own product internally to test/validate it
Applying game-design elements (Points, Badges, Leaderboards) to non-game contexts
Trigger -> Action -> Variable Reward -> Investment (Nir Eyal)
Unpredictable outcome that keeps users engaged (Slot machine effect)
Emotional response to a product that goes beyond mere usability (Delight)
Slow degradation of UX quality as new features are bolted on without holistic view
Users subconsciously ignore page elements that look like advertisements
Newspapers sold folded in half; top half visible on stand
Low discoverability (Out of sight, out of mind); lower engagement vs visible tabs
Users rarely click past 1st slide; banner blindness; accessibility issues
Can cause motion sickness; performance impact on mobile; usability issues if overused
Overriding default browser scrolling behavior (often feels laggy or unexpected)
Links/Buttons that don't explain what they do until you hover/click
Sensationalist headline/thumbnail designed to attract clicks, often misleading
Software/Hardware announced but never actually manufactured/canceled
Software with excessive features using disproportionate resources
Low-quality software bundled with hardware or other software
Business model: Basic service free, advanced features paid
Software as a Service (Subscription based cloud software)
Metric that looks good on paper but doesn't correlate to business success (e.g. Page views vs Sales)
Set of specific factors that Google considers important in a webpage's overall user experience (LCP, FID/INP, CLS)
Tool to check if a webpage is easy to use on a mobile device
Area of mobile screen easily reachable with the thumb while holding phone with one hand
Image that scales or changes source based on viewport size (srcset)
Scalable Vector Graphics: crisp at any size, small file size for simple shapes, code-editable
To guide attention, provide feedback, or explain relationships (not just decoration)
Unexpected positive interactions that create emotional connection
Hidden feature or message placed inside a program/site
Don't just say 'No data'; explain why and tell user how to add data (CTA)
Provide helpful links to get back on track, maybe search bar, and be friendly
Keep it short, allow skip, focus on value proposition not just features
Use sparingly; multiple popups annoy users; focus on context
Concept of modes (e.g. Edit Mode, View Mode) where same controls do different things
Users often forget which mode they are in, leading to mode errors
Reduces initial learning curve; builds power features as user expertise grows
New-skeuomorphism (Neumorphism) or depth-based design helping usability in flat UIs
Flat design with subtle shadows/depth to improve usability (Material Design is an example)
Lack of design system usage, rushed deadlines, inconsistent updates
Library is just the UI assets (Figma file); System includes documentation, code, principles, voice
Process dealing with how the system is maintained, updated, and how decisions are made

q: What is 'Contribution Model' in Design Systems?
o: How product teams can submit new components/changes back to the central system
Classification system (Categories, Tags) for organizing content
Open (Users create categories) vs Closed (Categories provided)
Testing where a user would click first to complete a task (87% success correlation)
10-item questionnaire used to measure usability perception (Standardized)
Expert review of an interface against established usability principles (Nielsen)
Evaluation of a product's compliance with accessibility standards (WCAG)
Voluntary Product Accessibility Template (Document describing accessibility conformance)
Accessible Rich Internet Applications (Attributes to improve semantics for screen readers)
Attribute defining what an element is (e.g. role='button')
Attribute defining nature of element (e.g. aria-label='Close')
Keeping keyboard focus within a modal/dialog until it is closed (Good practice)
Using meaningful tags (nav, main, button) vs generic containers (div, span)
Fluid Grids, Flexible Images, Media Queries
Technique to apply CSS only when specific conditions (width > 768px) are met
Writing styles for small screens first (default), then adding min-width media queries for larger
Writing styles for large screens first, then adding max-width media queries for smaller
Forces prioritization of content; usually results in cleaner/faster code (progressive enhancement)
Web app wrapped in a native container (access to some device features)
Component in native app that displays web content (browser window inside app)
Code bridging JavaScript to platform-specific APIs (Camera, Bluetooth)
Apple's design guidelines for iOS/macOS apps
Area of screen not obscured by notch, rounded corners, or home indicator
CSS media query (prefers-color-scheme: dark) or class toggling
Usually smaller than multiple individual font files combined (Efficient)
Modern image format providing superior compression for web images
Newer image format with even better compression than WebP (based on AV1)
Library for rendering After Effects animations in real time (JSON based)
Interactive animation tool/format (successor to Flare) designed for runtime manipulation
JavaScript library for creating 3D graphics in the browser (WebGL)
Web Graphics Library (API for rendering 2D/3D graphics hardware-accelerated)
Popular JS library for building UI components (Component-based architecture aligns with design systems)
Progressive JavaScript Framework for building UIs
Platform for building mobile and desktop web applications (Google)
Utility-first: building designs directly in markup using low-level utility classes
Popular CSS framework with pre-built components and grid system (Twitter origin)
Content Management System (WordPress, Webflow) allowing non-coders to update content
CMS providing content via API only (no built-in front-end presentation layer)
JavaScript, APIs, and Markup (Modern web dev architecture)
Tool generating full HTML pages at build time (Fast, Secure)
Rendering pages on the server on each request (Better SEO/Initial load for dynamic data)
Rendering pages in the browser using JavaScript (App-like feel)
Process of attaching event listeners to static HTML sent from server to make it interactive
Splitting code into smaller bundles to be loaded on demand
Updating code modules in the browser without full reload during development
Event when Git can't automatically resolve differences in code between two commits
Data is safely stored in your local database
Marked a modified file in its current version to go into your next commit
Changed the file but have not committed it to your database yet
File exists locally but Git is not watching it yet (New file)
List of files/patterns Git should intentionally not track (e.g. node_modules, .env)
Base breakpoints on content needs, not specific device widths (though common ones like 768px are standard)
Building for modern browsers first, then ensuring basic functionality works on older ones
Removing unused code from the final bundle during build process
Removing whitespace and shortening variable names to reduce file size
Newspaper term; content visible without unfolding. In web: visible without scrolling
Less strictly so, as users are accustomed to scrolling, but initial impression still matters
User eye scanning pattern for text-heavy content (Top bar, lower bar, vertical stem)
User eye scanning pattern for pages with less text/more visual hierarchy (Top left to bottom right)
Pattern describing general eye movement from Primary Optical Area (top left) to Terminal Area (bottom right)
Users consciously or unconsciously ignore information that looks like an advertisement
Place controls close to the object they affect (e.g. Edit button near the item)
Productivity soars when computer and user interact at a pace (<400ms) that ensures neither has to wait
The simplest solution is usually the correct one; avoid unnecessary complexity
80% of effects come from 20% of causes (e.g. 80% usage is on 20% of features)
Be conservative in what you do, be liberal in what you accept from others (Input validation)
Every application has an inherent amount of complexity that cannot be removed, only shifted (to dev or user)
People judge an experience largely based on how they felt at its peak and at its end
Users tend to remember the first and last items in a series best (Primacy/Recency)
Items that stand out (differ) from their peers are more likely to be remembered (CTA buttons)
People remember uncompleted or interrupted tasks better than completed ones (Progress bars exploit this)
UI carefully crafted to trick users into doing things they might not want to do (e.g. hidden unsubscribe)
Easy to get into, hard to get out of (e.g. Easy signup, impossible cancellation)
Guilting the user into opting in ('No, I don't like saving money')
Tricking you into publicly sharing more info about yourself than you intended
User sets out to do one thing, but a different, undesirable thing happens instead
Adverts that are disguised as other kinds of content or navigation
Product asks for your email or social permissions under the pretense of a desirable outcome, then spams contacts
Retailer makes it hard to compare price of an item with another item (e.g. different units)
Default settings that are beneficial to the company but harmful/annoying to user
Compare two versions of a webpage to see which one performs better
Graphical representation of data using colors to indicate level of activity (Clicks, Scroll)
Heatmap showing how far down the page users are scrolling
Heatmap showing where users click (or tap)
Technology that monitors eye movements to determine where a person is looking
Replaying a user's journey on a website to see exactly what they did
Mapping and analyzing the series of steps a user takes to reach a goal (Conversion)
Breaking data into related groups for analysis (e.g. Users who signed up in Jan vs Feb)
Interaction style where users act directly on objects (Drag and drop, pinch to zoom)
Make important buttons large and close to the cursor start position
Minimize choices to speed up decision making (Reduce cognitive load)
Follow conventions; users expect your site to work like others they know
Chunk content into groups of 5-9 items (7 plus/minus 2) to aid working memory
Laws of human perception that describe how humans group similar elements (Proximity, Similarity, Closure)
Objects that are close together are perceived as a group
Objects that look similar are perceived as a group
The brain fills in gaps to perceive a complete shape
The eye is compelled to move through one object and continue to another
The eye differentiates an object from its surrounding area (Background)
Elements that are symmetrical to each other tend to be perceived as a unified group
A property of an object that indicates how it can be used (Button looks clickable)
Visible mark that communicates where the action should take place (e.g. underline on link)
Relationship between controls and their movements and the results in the world (Stove knobs)
Sending back information about what action has been done and what has been accomplished
Limits on possible actions (Physical, Logical, Cultural) to prevent error
Asking test participants to verbalize their thoughts while performing a task
Testing a system that doesn't exist yet by having a human manually simulate the response behind the scenes
Show design for 5s, hide it, ask what they remember (Tests first impression/clarity)
Simplified text-only version of site structure to test findability (Reverse card sort)
Suite of usability testing tools (Treejack, OptimalSort)
Visualization of the process that a person goes through in order to accomplish a goal
Collaborative visualization used to articulate what we know about a particular type of user (Says, Thinks, Does, Feels)
Fictional character created to represent a user type that might use a site/brand
Story that describes how a persona interacts with the product to achieve a goal
Minimum Viable Product (Version with just enough features to satisfy early customers)
Linear project management approach (Requirements -> Design -> Dev -> Test)
5-day process for answering critical business questions through design, prototyping, and testing
Focus on the actual experience being designed rather than deliverables (Build-Measure-Learn)
Design process model: Discover, Define, Develop, Deliver (Diverge then Converge)
Human-centered approach to innovation (Empathize, Define, Ideate, Prototype, Test)
Diagram that visualizes the relationships between different service components (People, props, processes)
Total of all interactions a customer has with a brand (Support, Product, Marketing)
Focuses specifically on the interaction between user and product (Usability, Utility)
The space where interactions between humans and machines occur (Visuals, Controls)
Design of the interaction between users and products (Motion, Behavior, Time)
Writing clear, concise text for UIs (Microcopy)
Small bits of text on UI (Button labels, Error messages, Hints)
Voice is personality (consistent); Tone is mood (variable based on context)
Adapting a product for a specific locale (Language, Currency, Date format)
Designing a product so it can be easily adapted to various languages/regions without engineering changes
Support for both LTR (Left-to-Right) and RTL (Right-to-Left) languages
Flipping UI layout for RTL languages (e.g. Back button points right)
Testing method using fake characters to simulate foreign languages (Test expansion/encoding)
Placeholder text used to demonstrate visual form of a document

q: Why avoid 'Lorem Ipsum' in hi-fi prototypes?
o: Real content informs design decisions; Lorem Ipsum hides layout issues with realistic text lengths
Designing around the actual content rather than forcing content into a design
Degradation: Build for best -> Fallback. Enhancement: Build for base -> Improve.
Web app that interacts with user by dynamically rewriting current page rather than loading new pages
Progressive Web App: Web site that acts like a native app (Offline, Installable)
